source:
hong kong ( cnn ) six people were hurt after an explosion at a controversial chemical plant in china 's southeastern fujian province sparked a huge fire , provincial authorities told state media .
the plant , located in zhangzhou city , produces paraxylene ( px ) , a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in the production of polyester films and fabrics .
the blast occurred at an oil storage facility monday night after an oil leak , though local media has not reported any toxic chemical spill .
five out of six people were injured by broken glass and have been sent to the hospital for treatment , xinhua news agency reported .
more than 600 firefighters were sent to battle the blaze and the fire is now under control , the zhangzhou fire department wrote on their official microblogging account tuesday morning .
residents living close to the plant had heard the explosion and took to weibo to post photos of the fire .
one user wrote that he heard a loud blast and felt slight tremors .
the plant was hit by another explosion in july 2013 , although there were no reports of casualties or toxic leaks at the time .
though demonstrations are illegal in china , the construction of px plants has sparked protests , which have occasionally turned violent , in several cities in recent years .
the zhangzhou plant was slated for xiamen -- a densely populated city in the southeast of the country .
however , it provoked an angry backlash in 2007 due to pollution concerns and prompted the local government to relocate the factory to its current , more remote location .
summary: In the passage, an explosion at a paraxylene (px) producing chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, caused a fire. Six people were injured by broken glass and taken to the hospital. The fire, which occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, is now under control after 600 firefighters were sent to extinguish it. The plant, which is reportedly carcinogenic, has a history of protests due to pollution concerns, and was relocated to a more remote location in 2007 following public backlash. The plant was previously slated for Xiamen, a densely populated city in southeast China. There was no mention of toxic chemical spills in this incident, but the plant has a history of explosions, with the last one occurring in July 2013.

the plant , located in zhangzhou city , produces paraxylene ( px ) , a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in the production of polyester films and fabrics .

summary: An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province caused a fire, injuring six people. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, with no toxic chemical spill reported. Five of the injured were sent to the hospital, and over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire. The plant had previously experienced an explosion in 2013 with no casualties. The construction of PX plants has sparked protests in China, leading to the relocation of the Zhangzhou plant to a more remote location due to pollution concerns. Residents near the plant reported hearing the explosion and witnessing the fire on social media.

The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters brought the fire under control. This plant had experienced a previous explosion in 2013 and was relocated from Xiamen due to pollution concerns and protests in 2007. summary: A controversial chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, experienced an explosion and subsequent fire on Monday night. The blast, caused by an oil leak at an oil storage facility, resulted in six people being injured by broken glass, with five hospitalized. More than 600 firefighters controlled the fire. The plant produces paraxylene, a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. This incident follows another explosion in 2013 without casualties. Protests against PX plants, which can be violent, have occurred in various Chinese cities due to pollution concerns. The Zhangzhou plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was moved to its current location due to public opposition in 2007.
